snippet: Keeneland will soon replace its synthetic track with dirt, a surface that fatally broke down racehorses at a much greater rate from 2009 to 2013, according to the Jockey Club.
abstract: Joe Drape On Horse Racing column questions why Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky, is replacing its synthetic track with dirt after Jockey Club released statistics from its equine injury database showing that synthetic racetracks are far safer than dirt or turf, and Keeneland's track was one of the safest in the nation, with a fatality rate last year of 0.33 per 1,000 starts.
lead_paragraph: Keeneland will soon replace its synthetic track with dirt, a surface that fatally broke down racehorses at a much greater rate from 2009 to 2013, according to the Jockey Club.

headline.main: A Track’s Shift to Dirt Adds to Horses’ Risks
headline.print_headline: From a Synthetic Track to Dirt, and a Higher Risk for Horses
